title: Why the stock market is up, but everyone is down
text:
"Bosses get sucked into bull markets too," Buckland explained, as merger activity was the equivalent of 10 per cent of market capitalisation in the late 1990s, and about 8 per cent in 2007, compared to 4 to 5 per cent at the moment.

The lack of deals means bankers are not getting paid, and that explains why the sell-side isn't all that excited.

The fund managers on the buy-side, meanwhile, aren't having the best of times either. That's because fund flows aren't responding to the rising sharemarket as they have in the past.

Flat flows

Over the last two years, Buckland said in his presentation, net flows into equity funds are flat while passive investment strategies are capturing more capital.

A flurry of deals and a flood of cash into the sharemarket are two clear signs that the bull market is nearing the end. But this "euphoria" simply isn't there, and that suggests to Buckland that sharemarkets are not massively overvalued.

So markets could still run, but investors are getting mixed messages. The dreaded inverted yield curve, for instance, is indicating a recession may be looming and that would hit equity market returns.

Advertisement

So investors will have to make their own minds up as to whether to heed the warning of the inverted yield curve, or wait for a clearer signal of sharemarket excess.

The other head-scratching issue for the active fund managers is that markets are behaving very differently.

As Ian Heslop, the head of global equities at London-based Merian Global Investors showed, for the last 16 years, investors have tended to make money from buying cheap, high-quality companies, and selling or avoiding expensive, poor quality ones.

Dash for trash

But since March 2018, that has not worked at all in the US. Investors have been rewarded for buying "expensive" poor-quality equities, and punished for buying cheaper stocks that screen for quality factors.

Institutional investors have to determine whether this is a medium-term aberration, or if they have to change the way they think about markets.

The same applies to value managers. As has been discussed a "value" strategy of buying cheap stocks and selling expensive ones has failed miserably for the last five years.

Heslop is not convinced it's the right time to bet on the value factor coming good. He believes "value" stocks are cheap because they're risky, and the market simply does not have the risk appetite at this stage to bid up these stocks.

And, he argues, that so long as interest rates remain low, the valuation of stocks that seem expensive can potentially be justified, implying "value" may struggle.

And with large corporates less willing to take advantage of cheap funding to do deals, it seems interest rates may actually be a better barometer of capital markets' welfare than sharemarket indices.
description: Brokers and fund managers aren't enjoying the decade long bull market: bankers aren't getting paid, and fund flows aren't responding to the rising sharemarket.
